awd_titl_txt: Abelian Varieties, Hecke Orbits, and Specialization
awd_abstract_narration:
Elliptic curves (and their generalizations called abelian varieties) are fundamental mathematical objects that are also of great importance in other fields such as cryptography and error correcting codes. There are naturally occurring geometric spaces, called Shimura varieties, whose points classify different elliptic curves (and abelian varieties). Inside these spaces are orbits, called Hecke orbits. These orbits are not like the regular periodic orbits of the planets around the sun, but are highly unpredictable and chaotic. Indeed, each orbit is conjectured to be distributed equally throughout the Shimura variety. The principal investigator and his collaborators will use techniques from various areas of mathematics, including number theory, algebraic geometry and representation theory to study several aspects of these Hecke orbits. As part of this award the PI plans to introduce undergraduates to research in mathematics and to  train graduate students on topics related to the project.

The specific goals of this project are to understand the characteristic zero and characteristic p interplay of isogenies and Hecke orbits, keeping in mind applications to the long standing question of finding abelian varieties not isogenous to Jacobians. The PI also plans to study just-likely and unlikely intersections in Shimura varieties within the context of Hecke orbits, and to finally make progress towards understanding the dynamics of Hecke operators on mod p Shimura varieties, in the context of the Hecke Orbit conjecture.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The PI and his collaborators established results about families of K3 surfaces and abelian surfaces under specialization, and about the mod p and p-adic behavour of Hecke correspondences. These papers were published in Inventiones, Forum of Math. Pi., Compositio, JEMS and Math Annalen.

The PI and his collaborators also settled the Andre-Oort conjecture for exceptional Shimura varieties (and therefore, for all Shimura varieties), addressed the folklore question about abelian varieties and Jacobians by proving the existence of abelian varieties over global function fields that are not isogenous to Jacobians, made progress towards p-adic notions of hyperblicity for moduli spaces of abelian motives (including abelian Shimura varieties), and towards the existence of integral canonical models of Shimura varieties. The PI's graduate students wrote several papers while supported by this grant, including a p-adic monodromy theorem for K3 and abelian surfaces over local function fields, a characteristic p analogue of the Andre-Oort and Mumford-Tate conjectures, and about the p-adic distribution of the small-(p-adic arithmetic)monodromy locus in Shimura varieties.

 

The PI has spoken about this research at various seminars, conferences and workshops. The PI has also structured and deliverd a mini-course (at Berkeley) on the p-adic geometry of Shimura varieties, and has delivered a learning seminar on the Andre-Oort conjecture at MSRI (SL math). The PI, together with Emma Knight and Abhishek Oswal, has also created a project for the PROMYS program in Boston in the summer of 2022.
